trans-unit.source: Deploy an API app in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Deploy an API app in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Learn how to deploy an API app project to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to deploy an API app project to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you'll deploy the Web API project that you created in the <linkText>previous tutorial</linkText><title></title> to a new <linkText>API app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you'll deploy the Web API project that you created in the <linkText>previous tutorial</linkText><title></title> to a new <linkText>API app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You'll use Visual Studio to create the API app resource in <linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title> and to deploy your Web API code to the Azure API app.
trans-unit.target: You'll use Visual Studio to create the API app resource in <linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title> and to deploy your Web API code to the Azure API app.

trans-unit.source: There are many other ways to deploy API apps.
trans-unit.target: There are many other ways to deploy API apps.

trans-unit.source: An API app is a <linkText>web app</linkText><title></title> with extra features for hosting web services, and all of the <linkText>the deployment methods that are available for web apps</linkText><title></title> can also be used with API apps.
trans-unit.target: An API app is a <linkText>web app</linkText><title></title> with extra features for hosting web services, and all of the <linkText>the deployment methods that are available for web apps</linkText><title></title> can also be used with API apps.

trans-unit.source: The web app that hosts an API app is called the API app host in the Azure preview portal, and you can configure deployment by using the API app host portal blade.
trans-unit.target: The web app that hosts an API app is called the API app host in the Azure preview portal, and you can configure deployment by using the API app host portal blade.

trans-unit.source: For information about the API app host blade, see <linkText>Manage an API app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about the API app host blade, see <linkText>Manage an API app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The fact that API apps are based on web apps also means that you can deploy code written for platforms other than ASP.NET to API apps.
trans-unit.target: The fact that API apps are based on web apps also means that you can deploy code written for platforms other than ASP.NET to API apps.

trans-unit.source: For an example that uses Git to deploy Node.js code to an API app, see <linkText>Create a Node.js API app in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For an example that uses Git to deploy Node.js code to an API app, see <linkText>Create a Node.js API app in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you use the Visual Studio Publish Web wizard to create an API app in Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you use the Visual Studio Publish Web wizard to create an API app in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Where the instructions direct you to enter a name for the API app, enter ContactsList.
trans-unit.target: Where the instructions direct you to enter a name for the API app, enter ContactsList.

trans-unit.source: You use the same Publish Web wizard to deploy your code to the new API app.
trans-unit.target: You use the same Publish Web wizard to deploy your code to the new API app.

trans-unit.source: Since you enabled the Swagger UI in the previous tutorial, you can use that to verify that the API app is running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Since you enabled the Swagger UI in the previous tutorial, you can use that to verify that the API app is running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, go to the API app blade for the API app that you deployed.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, go to the API app blade for the API app that you deployed.

trans-unit.source: Click the API app's URL.
trans-unit.target: Click the API app's URL.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click the URL</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click the URL</linkText>

trans-unit.source: An "API app successfully created" page appears.
trans-unit.target: An "API app successfully created" page appears.

trans-unit.source: Add "/swagger" to the end of the URL in the browser address bar.
trans-unit.target: Add "/swagger" to the end of the URL in the browser address bar.

trans-unit.source: In the Swagger page that appears, click Contacts > Get > Try it Out.
trans-unit.target: In the Swagger page that appears, click Contacts > Get > Try it Out.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Try it out</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Try it out</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, go back to the API app blade for the API app that you deployed.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, go back to the API app blade for the API app that you deployed.

trans-unit.source: Click API Definition.
trans-unit.target: Click API Definition.

trans-unit.source: The app's API Definition blade shows the list of API operations that you defined when you created the app.
trans-unit.target: The app's API Definition blade shows the list of API operations that you defined when you created the app.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API Definition</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API Definition</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll make a change to the API definition and see the change reflected in the portal.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll make a change to the API definition and see the change reflected in the portal.

trans-unit.source: Go back to the project in Visual Studio and add the following code to the ContactsController.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Go back to the project in Visual Studio and add the following code to the ContactsController.cs file.

trans-unit.source: This code adds a Post method that can be used to post new Contact instances to the API.
trans-unit.target: This code adds a Post method that can be used to post new Contact instances to the API.

trans-unit.source: The code for the Contacts class now looks like the following example.
trans-unit.target: The code for the Contacts class now looks like the following example.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: Click the Preview tab
trans-unit.target: Click the Preview tab

trans-unit.source: Click Start Preview to see which file(s) will be copied to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Click Start Preview to see which file(s) will be copied to Azure.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish Web dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish Web dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Publish.
trans-unit.target: Click Publish.

trans-unit.source: Restart the gateway as you did the first time you published.
trans-unit.target: Restart the gateway as you did the first time you published.

trans-unit.source: Once the publish process has completed, go back to the portal, and close and reopen the API Definition blade.
trans-unit.target: Once the publish process has completed, go back to the portal, and close and reopen the API Definition blade.

trans-unit.source: You will see the new API endpoint you just created and deployed directly into your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: You will see the new API endpoint you just created and deployed directly into your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API Definition</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API Definition</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You've seen how the direct deployment capabilities in Visual Studio make it easy to iterate and deploy rapidly and test that your API works correctly.
trans-unit.target: You've seen how the direct deployment capabilities in Visual Studio make it easy to iterate and deploy rapidly and test that your API works correctly.

trans-unit.source: In the <linkText>next tutorial</linkText><title></title>, you'll see how to debug your API app while it runs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: In the <linkText>next tutorial</linkText><title></title>, you'll see how to debug your API app while it runs in Azure.
